objtitle.title: Blake's Annotations to Bacon's *Essays Moral, Economical, and Political.*

objdescid.origination: Francis Bacon author of the printed text
T. Bensley printer of the letterpress text

imprint.title: Essays Moral, Economical, and Political.
imprint.publisher: J. Edwards, Pall Mall, and T. Payne, Mews Gate

objdescid.compdate: c. 1798 Based on the content of Blake's marginalia, Bentley (page 682) suggests the annotations were made shortly after the edition's publication in 1798.

objinfo.numberobj: 91There are annotations on 91 pages (70 leaves) out of the 270 total pages (not inlcuding flyleaves) of the printed book. We have reproduced only the objects bearing annotations.
objinfo.binding: Bound in green cloth over the original boards; some pages are now loose.

provenance.name: Cambridge University Library

lg.l: Is it True or is it False that the
Wisdom of this World is Foolishness
If what Bacon says Is True
Good Advice for Satans Satan's Kingdom
I am astonishdastonished how such Contemptible
Knavery & Folly as this Book contains
can ever have been calldcalled Wisdom by
Men of Sense but perhaps this never
was the cCase & all Men of Sense haveBlake wrote this line over the printed title "P R E F A C E."The capitol "C" in "Case" appears to have been written over a lowercase "c".
dispiseddespised the Book as MuchasMuch as I doErdman reads "dispised" as "despised" and Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1425) and Erdman read "Muchas" as "Much as"(620).
Per William BlakeThe unclear "P" in "Per" appears to be written over an incomplete character. Bentley (*Writings* vol 2, page 1425) and Erdman (620) read "Per" with confidence.
to MensMen'sbusiness andBlake has underlined the phrase "business and" in the printed text.
"bosoms,"Blake has underlined "bosoms,'" in the printed text.
Every Body Everybody Knows that this is EpiEpicurus
-curusEpicurus & Lucretius & Yet Every Body Everybody Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1425) and Erdman (620) read the first ampersand in this line as "and".
Says that it is Christian PhilosopyPhilosophyBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1425) and Erdman (620) read "Philosopy" as "Philosophy".
how is this Possible Every Body Everybody
must be a Liar & decieverdeceiver but
Every Body Everybody does not do this But
It was a Common opinion in
the Court of Queen Elizabeth that
Knavery Is Wisdom. CunningErdman replaces the period at the end of this line with a colon (620).
Self Evident Self-Evident Truth is one ThingThe characters "in" in "Thing" are poorly formed.
and Truth the result of Reasoning is
another Thing Rational Truth is not
the Truth of Christ but of Pilate
PretencePretense to The "c" in "Pretence" is poorly formed.
to ManThe "a" in "Man" is poorly formed.
Bacon put an End to Faith
False Ounknown to the heathen.Blake has underlined part of the phrase, "unknown to the heathen", in the printed text.
Prophets poets.Blake has underlined the word "poets" in the printed text.
Did not Jesus descend & become a Servant
The Prince of darkness is a Gentleman &
not a Man he is a Lord Chancellor
nakedness is uncomely, FollyBlake has underlined the phrase "nakedness is uncomely," in the printed.
& tells into The erasure in the line below has partially affected the bottom half of this line.
the hands of a Tyrant There is illegible text directly after "Tyrant" that has been erased.
Bacon was afraid to say that the Envy
was upon a King but is This Envy
Christs Christ's Acts were Nothing to Caesers Caesar's
A Flogging Magistrate I have seen
many such fly blows of Bacon

l.note: The second "e" in "Every" is poorly formed.

objnote.p: On the right-hand margin of this page, Blake has drawn a vertical chain spanning the length of the page and the last link in the chain encircles the phrase, "A King". Bentley notes that remnants of an erased image and some script are located at the top of the chain and suggests that the erased portion is a buttocks captioned with the phrase: "The Devils arse" (*Writings* vol 2, 1430). Erdman suggests the chain is excremented from "The Devils arse" (624). For further reading, see "Blake, Bacon and 'The Devils Arse'", *Blake/An Illustrated Quarterly* 37.4 (spring 2004) by Robert W. Rix.

illustration.illusobjdesc: What looks like a chain descends in the right margin, although it could be excrement descending from an erased figure upper right. See the Editors’ Note on this motif.

component.illusobjdesc: What looks like a chain descends in the right margin, although it could be excrement descending from an erased figure upper right. See the Editors’ Note on this motif.

lg.l: democracies they needBlake has partially underlined the phrase, "democracies they need", in the printed text.

l.note: Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1431) and Erdman (624) read "SelfContradiction" as "Self Contradiction".

lg.l: commonly more quiet, and lessBlake has partially underlined the phrase, "commonly more quiet, and less" in the printed text.
to be InnocentsInnocenceBentley omits the "s" from "Innocents" (*Writings* volume 2, page 1431).

l.note: Blake has underlined the word "equality" in the printed text.

lg.l: of GovernmentBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1432) and Erdman (624) transcribe "Government" with certainty.
SizedsThe final "s" in "Sizes" appears to be written over a "d".
or Intellectual Acquirement. Man is not
Improved by the hurt of another States are not
Improved at the Expense of Foreigners
forthefor the DevilBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1433) and Erdman (625) read "forthe" as "for the".
can be except Factious is Christianity

l.note: Blake has underlined the word "mind" in the printed text.

lg.l: as a SecondThe word "Second" is partially faded toward the edge of the page.
r as aBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1434) and Erdman (626) read the partially illegible word in this line as "nor".
a ContemplatBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1434) and Erdman (626) read the partially illegible word in this line as "Contemplative" with certainty.
Lucian disbelievddisbelieved Heathen Gods he did not
perhaps disbelieve for all that Bacon did

objnote.p: Bentley mistakenly records this page of Bacon's *Essays* as "79" instead of page "78" (*Writings* volume 2, pages 1434-1435). He also erroneously records that the first five lines of Blake's annotations on the actual page "79" (Object 44) are located on this page (*Writings* volume 2, pages 1434-1435).

lg.l: A Lie adversitiesBlake has partially underlined the word "adversities" in the printed text.Erdman reads "A" as "a" (626).

Artifice{Blake has drawn what appears to be a bracket originating from "Artifice", the ends of which terminate near the words "nobility" and "God" in the printed text, emphasizing 3 lines from the text. The lower line of the bracket appears to underline "God". A short line also extends from "An" in the preceding line to the midpoint of the bracket.

objnote.p: Bentley erroneously records that the first five lines of Blake's marginalia on this page are located on the previous page (*Writings* volume 2, page 1435).
Blake has underlined multiple words and portions of words throughout this object.

lg.l: What must our Clergy be who Allow
Bacon to be Either Wise or even of
the peopleBlake has partially underlined the phrase, "the people" in the printed text.

BaconsBacon's\ VillanVillain is a Kig or Who Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1435) and Erdman (627) read "Bacons" and "King" with confidence, and read "Villan" as "Villain".Erdman proposes that the back-slash stroke after "Bacons" is a caret pointing to "Reformer" in the previous line, indicating that line 5 could be read as "Bacons Reformer Villian" (885).
The ThingBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1436) and Erdman (627) read "Thing" as "Things".

l.note: Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1436) and Erdman (627) read the partially legible word preceding "Trumpery" as "the".

lg.l: he couldThe word "could" appears to be partially written over illegible, deleted text.
Nothig of Arts or Artists or Learnd MenBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1436) and Erdman (627) read "Nothing" and "Learned" with confidence.
or of Agriculture or any Useful ThigBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1436) and Erdman (627) read "Thing" with confidence.
His Business & Bosom was to be Lord Chancellor
Bacon supposes that the Dragon Beast & HarlotBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1436) reads "Dragon" as "dragon".
are worthy of a Place in the New Jerusalem
Do thisBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1436) and Erdman (627) read "Do" as "do".
quality residingBlake has underlined "quality" and the first letter of "residing" in pencil.

l.note: Blake has underlined "favour" in the printed text.

lg.l: few ThigsBentley (*Writings* volume 2, 1437) and Erdman (627) read "Things" with confidence.
a King & {Blake has bracketed the second paragraph of the printed text; the peak of the bracket points to the ampersand.
have beenThe first "e" in "been" is poorly formed.
ShapenErdman (628) and Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1438) read "Shapen" as "shapen".
because theyThe "y" in "they" is obscured by the wear of the paper's edge.
are not yetThe tail of the "y" in "they" in the preceding line runs through the "e" in "yet" in this line.
FoolThere appears to be a stray mark at the end of "Fool".
the Poor it Erdman inserts a comma after "Poor" (629).
them— IfThe ampersand is poorly formed.Erdman (629) reads the m-dash after "them" with confidence while Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1439) omits it.
to the RichErdman inserts a comma after "Rich" (629).
If to theThe "o" in "to" is poorly formed.
Middle Class it is the direct Contrary to

l.note: Blake has underlined "certainties." in the printed text.

lg.l: what SuchBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1439) and Erdman (629) read "Such" as "such".
Powers of princes PrincesBlake has underlined the word "Princes" in the printed text.Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1439) and Erdman (629) read "Princes" with certainty.
darkness PowrsBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1439) and Erdman (629) read "Powers" with certainty.
Bacon knows the Wisdom of War if it is

l.note: Blake has underlined "greatest monarchy." in the printed text.

lg.l: Arts UnmanlyThe last three letters of "Unmanly" are written over the printed text.
Poetry PaintigBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1440) and Erdman (629) read "Painting" with certainty.
Useless &The final "s" in "Useless" is poorly formed.
what canBentley reads "what" as "What" (*Writings* volume 2, page 1441).
foolishThere appear to be two small slash marks to the top left of the "f" in "foolish".
FalseThere appears to be a small, stray pencil mark running vertically through the bottom half of the "F".
but for NecessityBentley reads "Necessity" as "necessity" (*Writings* volume 2, page 1441).
Those thatThe "a" in "that" is poorly formed.
[Blake has drawn a bracket extending from the word "inclination" to the word "masteries" in the printed text, highlighting this section.
or discernmentBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1442) and Erdman (630) read "discernment" as "Discernment".
it is FollyErdman (630) reads a period after "Folly".
never talkdtalkedBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1442) and Erdman (630) read the illegible "e" in "talkd" with certainty.

is descretdiscretionThe last characters of the partially illegible word "descret" [sic] are not visible due to a puckering of the paper near the gutter of the page. Bentley reads the partially illegible word as "discretion" with confidence (*Writings* volume 2, page 1442). Erdman reads the word as "discret[io]n" (630).

one So foolisfoolishErdman reads "So" as "so" (631).The "h" in "foolish" is not visible due to curling of the page along its edge. Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1442) and Erdman (631) read "foolish" with confidence.
then goneThere appears to be extra pencil marks beneath the "th" in "then".
& nothignothingBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1443) and Erdman (631) read "nothing" with confidence.

l.note: Blake appears to have merged the final "e" in "Else" with the tail of the "g" in "nothig" in the previous line. Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1443) and Erdman (631) read "Else" with confidence.

lg.l: CruellThe "e" in "Cruel" appears to be written over an "l".

Man saysaysThe "M" in "Man" appears to be written over an illegible character.Blake seems to have omitted the "s" at the end of "say". Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1443) and Erdman (631) read "says" with confidence.
& his PhilophyPhilosophyBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1443) and Erdman (631) read "Philosophy" with confidence.
stupidBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1444) and Erdman (632) read "stupid" as "Stupid".
Kings do ItBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1444) and Erdman (632) read "It" as "it".
What palace,Blake has underlined "palace," in the printed text.

l.note: The apparent ampersand is partially obscured by stray marks and parts of letter overlapping in the line below.
Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1444) and Erdman (632) read "SelfConeit" as "Self Conceit".

lg.l: King James was Bacons Bacon's Primum Mobile

l.note: Blake has underlined the phrase "small matters" in the printed text.

lg.l: Small matters What are TheyBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1445) reads "matters" as "Matters".
Caesar seems to me a Very Small Matter
& so he seemdseemed to Jesus is the devil Great
common people,VillainBlake has underlined the phrase "common people," in the printed text.
dod ChristBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1445) and Erdman (632) read "dod" as "did".
